title: 114_hr624
content: The Act is titled the "Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act" defines terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "foreign person," and "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights." The "Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act" defines "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" as including torture, arbitrary detention, and denial of basic rights. It also clarifies that "person" refers to an individual or entity, and "United States person" includes citizens, lawful residents, and entities organized under U.S. laws. Entities within the United States, including foreign branches. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF IMPOSITION OF SANCTIONS. The President shall impose sanctions on any foreign person responsible for extrajudicial killings, torture, or gross human rights violations, particularly against those exposing illegal activities or promoting internationally recognized human rights. Sanctions may be imposed on foreign persons who act on behalf of a foreign entity in corrupt activities, government officials involved in significant corruption, or those who support such activities financially or materially. The sanctions include measures to address extrajudicial killings, torture, and gross human rights violations. Sanctions may include inadmissibility to the United States for foreign individuals and blocking of property transactions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act may involve blocking property and interests of foreign persons in the United States or under the control of a U.S. person. The President considers information from congressional committees and other countries when deciding on sanctions. The President considers credible information from other countries and organizations monitoring human rights violations. Upon request from congressional committees, the President must determine if a foreign person has engaged in prohibited activities and submit a report on potential sanctions. The President may impose sanctions on a person, with a description of those sanctions. Sanctions can be waived for national security interests if deemed necessary, with notification to congressional committees. Sanctions do not apply if admitting an individual is required to comply with the United Nations Headquarters Agreement. The President can impose sanctions on individuals, which can be waived for national security reasons. Sanctions do not apply if compliance is necessary under international agreements. Violators will face penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The President has the authority to lift sanctions if deemed appropriate. The President can impose sanctions on individuals, which can be waived for national security reasons. Sanctions may be terminated if credible information shows the person did not engage in sanctioned activity, was prosecuted appropriately, or has shown a significant change in behavior and committed to not repeat the activity. The President has the authority to issue regulations, licenses, and orders to enforce this section. The President is required to submit reports to Congress. The President must submit an annual report to Congress listing foreign persons sanctioned under section 3, describing the sanctions imposed, and providing the number of persons sanctioned and sanctions terminated during the year. Dates of sanctions imposed or terminated must also be included. The President must submit an annual report to Congress listing foreign persons sanctioned under section 3, describing the sanctions imposed, reasons for imposing or terminating sanctions, and efforts to encourage other countries to impose similar sanctions. Initial report due within 120 days of enactment, subsequent reports on December 10 or the first day. The President must submit an annual report to Congress listing foreign persons sanctioned under section 3, describing the sanctions imposed, reasons for imposing or terminating sanctions, and efforts to encourage other countries to impose similar sanctions. Reports are due within 120 days of enactment and subsequently on December 10 or the first day thereafter when both Houses of Congress are in session. Congress recognizes December 10 as "Human Rights Day" and emphasizes its significance for the submission of reports each year. The report required by subsection (a) must be submitted annually to Congress in unclassified form, with the option to include a classified annex if deemed vital for national security interests by the President. The President must use the annex in line with congressional intent and the Act's purposes. Additional information in the unclassified report includes the total number of foreign persons, distinguishing between individuals and entities. The unclassified report required by the President must include the country of citizenship for individuals and the country of organization for entities. The report will be made public, including publication in the Federal Register, without confidentiality requirements for visa records. The unclassified report required by the President must include citizenship and organization country details, to be made public without visa record confidentiality requirements. The Comptroller General will report to Congress on the implementation of this act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on the process of determining sanctions for foreign persons and the implementation of the Act, consulting with relevant parties. The Comptroller General will consult with appropriate congressional committees and nongovernmental organizations to prepare the required report on sanctions for foreign persons.
